urn:contentItem:5TR8-MV31-F0J6-J2K3-00000-00Planned fuel reduction burn at Little Desert2018-11-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisPlanned fuel reduction burn at Little Desert

FOREST Fire Management Victoria has advised community members that a planned fuel reduction burn at Little Desert will start on Thursday, weather permitting.

The 108 hectare burn will be competed between 12noon and 6pm on November 15, with an end date of Thursday, November 22 expected.

The burn objective is to develop fuel reduced areas of sufficient width and continuity to reduce the speed and intensity of bushfires.

FFMV has advised the community that they may be affected by smoke from the planned burns and smoke may be visible from Little Desert National Park.

If you experience any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

Close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering.

Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke. Signs may be in place to slow traffic.

Obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn.

Be aware of planned burns happening in your local area and stay clear of areas where burns are taking place or areas that have recently been burnt.

urn:contentItem:5T4N-0NC1-JD34-V13C-00000-00Spring firewood pick-up starting2018-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisLIFEPg. 33Spring firewood pick-up starting

Collection of firewood from designated public land will open on Saturday, with the spring season running until the end of September.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume assistant chief fire officer Jarrod Hayse said there would be no collection areas in River Red Gum parks this year, and reminded residents of limits.

"You may collect up to two cubic metres of firewood per person per day, and up to 16 cubic metres per household per year; this prevents households stockpiling large volumes of firewood," he said.

"Some designated firewood collection areas may not open at the beginning of the season for various reasons, including supply or accessibility due to wet conditions.

"The felling of any trees for firewood is strictly prohibited and it's also illegal to sell firewood collected on public land without an appropriate permit or licence."

For more information visit ffm.vic.gov.au/firewood, or to report illegal removal of firewood, call 136 186.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA have advised of a 779 hectare planned burn in the Greater Bendigo National Park near Brights Lane, 13 kilometres north of Bendigo. urn:contentItem:5T3K-4PN1-F0J6-J41G-00000-00Firewood off limits in Gunbower2018-08-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Firewood off limits in Gunbower

Firewood collectors will not be able to use the Gunbower State Forest for the 2018 Spring season as an environmental watering program is underway, closing tracks and roads.

Forest Fire Management Victoria District Manager Paul Bates said watering by the North Central Catchment Management Authority in Gunbower Island had closed numerous thoroughfares in the forest over the past couple of months.

Mr Bates said he expected the Autumn firewood collection season to open in the forest in March 2019.

He said the closest open firewood collection area to the forest, near Cohuna, was Inglewood.

Despite this, Mr Bates said the Spring firewood collection season for 2018 would begin in earnest across Victoria on September 1.

He said firewood collection will once again be legal from designated areas on public land across the state.

The Spring collection season runs through to November 30.

"It's important that people only collect firewood from designated collection areas in state forests or parks where collection is allowed, and to stay within collection limits," he said.

urn:contentItem:5S66-KTJ1-F0J6-J3CX-00000-00444 hectare planned burn for the Grampians2018-04-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisNEWS444 hectare planned burn for the Grampians

A planned burn for Victoria Valley Road in the Grampians started yesterday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA plan on burning 444 hectares, with the burn expected to go until Sunday.

FFMV and the CFA have advised some people may be affected by the smoke.

The Department of Health and Human Services advises anyone experiencing symptoms of smoke exposure to seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024. The FFMV and the CFA also advise people to close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering, if affected by smoke exposure.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

To stay informed of the burn download the Vic Emergency app or call the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and their partners at CFA are carrying out more planned burning operations across the Gippsland region as the weather conditions improve. Assistant Chief Officer, Chris Stephenson said: "Burns are planned, or have been ignited from Noojee, Neerim East and Boolarra through to Rosedale, Briagolong, Dargo, Bruthen, Buchan, Nowa Nowa, Orbost and Bendoc." urn:contentItem:5TG1-JC91-F0J6-J46M-00000-00Fuel reduction burned planned for bush near Inglewood2018-10-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Fuel reduction burned planned for bush near Inglewood

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA plan to carry out a fuel reduction burn near Inglewood on Friday, if weather conditions permit.

The burn will be completed between 9am and 8pm in the Inglewood State Forest, two kilometres north of the township, but smoke might be visible until Monday.

Related: Fire conditions equal to some of Victoria's worst seasons

People in the area are advised to keep windows and doors closed.

Anyone who suffers possible smoke exposure symptoms should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 606 024.

Related: Planned burns to begin in central Victoria

The burn is one of several scheduled to take place in central Victoria this week ahead of the bushfire season.

Two separate burns are planned for locations south-west of Maryborough on Friday and Saturday.

urn:contentItem:5RC5-KD61-JD34-V46M-00000-00Brief lightning storm ignites multiple bushfires2018-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisBrief lightning storm ignites multiple bushfiresSophie Boyd

Firefighters responded to multiple bushfires yesterday after a brief lightning storm struck the Border and North East Victoria.

Country Fire Authority and Forest Fire Management Victoria crews worked to manage a one-hectare fire nine kilometres south-west of Eskdale near Penny Flat. A Fire Forest Management spokesman said two fixed wing aircraft dropped retardant on the blaze, which was brought under control by 5pm.

The spokesman said a crew would remain patrolling the fire to extinguish any hotspots overnight. CFA District 24 Duty Officer Ashley Mills said firefighters and Albury's Bomber 360 quickly contained two small fires around Tallangatta which were also ignited by lightning.

CFA also assisted NSW Rural Fire Service at a fire near Talmalmo.

urn:contentItem:5SB2-3831-F0J6-J109-00000-00Planned burns in the Grampians2018-05-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisNEWSPlanned burns in the GrampiansAlice Rennison

Forest Fire Management Victoria are aiming to do planned burns in the Grampians over the next few months.

"We're planning on doing burns in places such as Mount William," FFMV Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said.

"Around spring time we are planning on doing township burns in Stawell and Ararat.

"These are critical to the town."

FFMV did planned burns around the Grampians region last week, including in Pomonal and Boronia Track.

In early May a bushfire sparked near Boronia Track, after a private planned burn got out of control. The bushfire was quickly controlled.

Planned burns "are important", Mr Rudolph said.

"People can do their own burns on private property."

Fire restrictions ended at the start of May, but the CFA are still urging people to be careful.

Mr Rudolph urges people planning to do private burns to "contact the CFA if you're in doubt".

A 183-hectare burn at Towong Upper and a 94ha burn at Winton Wetlands were among dozens ignited by Forest Fire Management Victoria this week.

Chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi said weather conditions were ideal for planned burning to significantly reduce the bushfire risk.

"We are taking action now to protect Victoria next summer," she said.

"We understand that smoke from planned burning can affect some people and appreciate everyone's patience."

urn:contentItem:5T93-PSJ1-JD3N-538B-00000-00Burn-offs under way2018-09-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Burn-offs under wayBy PETER HUNT

SPRING fuel reduction burns have begun across Victoria in a bid to reduce forest fuel loads and curb the risk of catastrophic bushfires this summer.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said the planned burns were focused in high-risk communities, weather conditions permitting.

"Underlying dryness across the state and the potential for an early fire season will limit our burning opportunities, but when conditions are right we will take the opportunity to reduce bushfire risk," Mr Hardman said.

While the Andrews Government has set a residual risk target of 70 per cent or less, FFMVic reports show the risk in Victoria's most populous East Central zone has risen to 76 per cent.

Last year FFMVic reported "if we cannot carry out our planned fuel management activities, modelling indicates residual risk will rise steeply to 76 per cent within three years".For the latest information about when planned burns are happening near you, visit www.ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn or call 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5S66-KTJ1-F0J6-J3K0-00000-00444 hectare planned burn for the Grampians2018-04-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8444 hectare planned burn for the Grampians

A planned burn for Victoria Valley Road in the Grampians started yesterday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA plan on burning 444 hectares, with the burn expected to go until Sunday.

FFMV and the CFA have advised some people may be affected by the smoke.

The Department of Health and Human Services advises anyone experiencing symptoms of smoke exposure to seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024. The FFMV and the CFA also advise people to close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering, if affected by smoke exposure.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

To stay informed of the burn download the Vic Emergency app or call the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5S54-RWF1-F0J6-J3MM-00000-00Planned burn set for Tarnagulla State Forest near Dunolly2018-04-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisPlanned burn set for Tarnagulla State Forest near Dunolly

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA will conduct a planned burn in Dunolly on Sunday.

A fuel reduction burn on Dunolly-Noose Track, 5 kilomtres north of Dunolly will be in the Tarnagulla State Forest.

It will completed between 9am and 8pm on Sunday but smoke may be visible up until Tuesday.

Smoke may be visible from Dunolly and Tarnagulla.

Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke and access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

Anyone affected by smoke exposure, should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

For parks closures, please refer to Parks Victoria on 13 1963 or visit http://parkweb.vic.gov.au/

For more details on planned burns in Victoria visit www.ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn

urn:contentItem:4MKJ-RFS0-TXDB-G2XB-00000-00Brown doesn't believe forest fire will impact on court case2006-12-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisBrown doesn't believe forest fire will impact on court case

Greens Senator Bob Brown does not believe a bushfire burning in Tasmania's south-east has destroyed the habitat of the rare Wyelangta stag beetle.

It appears an area of the Wyelangta state forest, which is the subject of a Federal Court case, has been damaged by fire days before a decision on the case is to be handed down.

Senator Brown has been waging a legal battle to stop logging in the forest, arguing it could threaten rare species such as the beetle, the swift parrot and the Tasmanian wedgetail eagle.

A decision on the case is expected to be handed down on Tuesday.

While the extent of the damage to the area in question is not yet known, Senator Brown does not think it will impact on his case.

"It will take a very hot fire to damage or eliminate beetles from that habitat but the beetles have been there for hundreds of thousands of years, and they've experienced quite a few fires in the past," he said.

"I'm absolutely sure this fire is not going to lead to their elimination."

The fire in the Wyelangta forest region continues to burn but mild weather yesterday has allowed fire crews to strengthen containment lines.

The blaze has now burnt 11,500 hectares of bush.

Forest Fire Management Victoria will start the North East's planned burning program in coming weeks to reduce the risk of bushfires. Crews will focus efforts around Wangaratta, Beechworth, Mt Beauty, Bright, Eskdale, Dartmouth and Granya. Residents and visitors may see and smell smoke, and some roads and parks may have to be closed for public safety while burns are being undertaken. For your health and safety, you can find out when planned burns are happening by visiting vic.gov.au/plannedburn.

urn:contentItem:5PY7-9NG1-F0J6-J3WV-00000-00Planned burn for Castlemaine region2017-11-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisPlanned burn for Castlemaine regionMark Kearney

Fire authorities will this week carry out planned burns south of Bendigo, with residents being warned to expect the sight of smoke.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA have advised smoke might be visible from properties in Castlemaine and Harcourt while burns are conducted in the Walmer state forest.

Weather conditions permitting, the two agencies anticipate a 10.3-hectare fuel reduction 2.5 kilometres north west of Castlemaine and a 24.2 hectare burn 3.5 kilometres north east of the town.

The burns should be completed between 10am and 8pm on Tuesday, although smoke could persist until Thursday.

Residents can sign up for automated notifications about planned burns near them at the website www.delwp.vic.gov.au/pbns

urn:contentItem:5T0C-K331-F0J6-J516-00000-00Planned burn for Jilpanger Nature Conservation Reserve2018-08-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisPlanned burn for Jilpanger Nature Conservation ReserveDaina Oliver

THE Jilpanger Nature Conservation Reserve will be subject to a planned burn on Thursday.

The Country Fire Authority and Forest Fire Management Victoria's burn will take place in the Jilpanger Nature Conservation Reserve about 20 kilometres west of Toolondo between noon and 6pm.

The groups will continue the burn into Friday and patrol the area over the weekend to ensure the fire does not reignite.

The objective of the burn is to reduce the chances of a bushfire in the area and seed crop for red tail black cockatoo.

Roads in the area might be affected, and people are advised to stay clear. Smoke might be visible across the Wimmera.

Related: Authorities call for action as early bushfire season looms

If you are experiencing any symptoms that might be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

For more information and to stay informed on the planned burn, you can visit: ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn.

urn:contentItem:5CKY-98R1-JDKC-R18B-00000-00MESSAGE FOR CLOSEBURN CANCELLED2014-07-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisMESSAGE FOR CLOSEBURN CANCELLED

BRISBANE, Queensland, July 7 -- The Queensland Department of Community Safety issued the following news release:

Please be advised the ADVICE message for Closeburn has been cancelled.

The below information is now current.

Closeburn - forest fire as at 9.30am Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) crews have contained a forest fire around McDowells Rd and Mt Samson Rd, Closeburn. Rural crews remain on scene. The fire started at 2am and there is no threat to property. A smoke hazard is expected to affect the area today. Residents are asked to keep their doors and windows closed, and motorists should drive to conditions. If required, respiratory medication should also be kept close by. If residents are concerned their property is under threat, they should call triple zero (000) immediately. Up to 40 New Zealand firefighters will fly into Victoria this week to help with the state's planned burning program. "We're working with New Zealand National Rural Fire Authority to secure short-term additional firefighters to help deliver Victoria's planned burning program," Forest Fire Management Victoria acting chief fire officer Darrin McKenzie said. NZ firefighters will spend about 10 days helping Victorian crews. For information about planned burns go to ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn or phone 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5MFC-KSW1-F0J6-J337-00000-00Planned burns put on delay2016-12-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Planned burns put on delayChris Young

PLANNED fuel reduction burns near Towong and Cudgewa were delayed to a later date after weather conditions failed to suit.

A 1.6-hectare burn along Towong Hill Road and a 6.4-hectare burn near the Cudgewa railway were abandoned on Thursday.

Both fuel reduction burns will be re-scheduled, subject to fuel load and weather conditions in the days to come, a Forest Fire Victoria spokesman said.

urn:contentItem:5RGN-MKK1-JD3N-54N5-00000-00FIRIES KEEP CAREFUL WATCH ON FOREST2018-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13FIRIES KEEP CAREFUL WATCH ON FOREST

FIRE crews were last night monitoring a fire burning on the Tweed Coast as the impact on Kings Forest wildlife is assessed.

The blaze was sparked by a vehicle fire at the end of Depot Rd, which spread to nearby grass and bushland about 10.45am on Tuesday.

Tweed Byron Police District officers said an elderly male driver was taken to hospital after the incident.

Incident controller and Tweed Coast Rural Fire Brigade captain Jared Lee said the fire - which has burnt through about 120 hectares - was now "fully contained" but would continue to smoulder for several days.

"Our containment lines are very strong at the moment," Mr Lee said.A spokesman for Leda Holdings, the developer that owns the Kings Forest site, said an ecologist was dispatched to assist wildlife.

urn:contentItem:5MS1-0TW1-F0JP-W18W-00000-00IT stalwart earns medal2017-01-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5IT stalwart earns medal

FAIRFIELD'S Philip Pringuer was awarded an Australian Fire Service Medal last week for his exemplary work with Forest Fire Management Victoria.

He has spent 18 years creating and maintaining fire prevention and manage-ment IT systems for the department, which are crucial during emergencies.

Chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi praised Mr Pringuer."These awards highlight the contributions of Mr Pringuer in preparing for and managing fires in the Victorian landscape behind the scenes over many years," Dr Rotarangi said.

urn:contentItem:4P6W-1CH0-TXN5-R2Y8-00000-00Vagrant's forest fire risked major blaze, court told2002-01-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 4Vagrant's forest fire risked major blaze, court toldLisa Carty, and Malcolm Brown

A vagrant who started a blaze in a pine forest during a total fire ban threatened a passer-by who tried to douse the flames, Bowral Local Court was told yesterday.

Gregory Manning Davidson, 47, had been playing cards on Sunday in Penrose State Forest, in the Southern Highlands, while the fire took hold, police said.

Police said they found three cigarette lighters and a roll of toilet paper stained with charcoal on Davidson after arresting him.

A passer-by, Oddmund Harstad, said he spotted the smoke from his car and ran into forest, where he claimed he found Davidson standing near a 1.5 metre-wide fire.

He said he tried to put the fire out but was threatened by Davidson. He left the scene to raise the alarm.

Police told the court the fire risked a major blaze.

Davidson, who is charged with maliciously damaging property by fire was remanded in custody and ordered to reappear at Picton Local Court on January 24.

Meanwhile, a committee has been set up decide how money from the Christmas 2001 Bushfire Relief Appeal is to be distributed. The Government has pledged $2 million, with another $1 million donated by the public.

urn:contentItem:5TCW-B831-JD3N-50S1-00000-00Street Watch2018-10-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Street Watch

YARRA RANGES Authorities are warning the community to be careful with campfires during the spring school holidays. Forest Fire Management Victoria assistant chief fire officer Jarrod Hayse said there had been 17 fires on public land across the region, with six caused by campfire negligence. "Most recently, a suspected unattended campfire caused a 3ha fire â€¦ luckily fire crews were able to contain the fire before it spread," Mr Hayse said. "Unattended campfires can lead to bushfires, placing the community and firefighters at risk, as well as potentially damaging the environment."CHIRNSIDE PARK A drugged-up man, caught driving into oncoming traffic on a major Bayswater North road will face court. The 36-year-old Chirnside Park man's black Ford Falcon was T-boned on Canterbury Rd, just before 4pm on Thursday, September 20. Maroondah highway patrol Sergeant Michael Aston said the man made a U-turn at Grayview Ave into oncoming traffic when his car was hit. Sgt Aston said a female passenger in the car was rushed to hospital with serious injuries. Sgt Aston said the man was charged with 11 offences including dangerous driving, drug driving, driving while suspended and drug possession.

urn:contentItem:5MHV-HGK1-JD34-V3V7-00000-00Campers urged to be aware2017-01-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:40ZLexisNexisCampers urged to be aware

HOLIDAYMAKERS are reminded to check the weather forecast and fire danger before heading into the Hume region's forests and parks.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's assistant chief fire officer - Hume Gill Metz said people should always keep in mind the potential for bushfires. Tips include taking plenty of food, water and extra fuel and packing sturdy footwear, a set of woollen clothing and a woollen blanket.

"Remember the weather can change rapidly," Ms Metz said.
